title: Economic Means of Foreign Policy: Geoeconomics from the British East India Company to China ExIm
description: States have long used economic means to advance political ends in the realm of foreign affairs, and political means to advance economic ends, a historical reality that contemporary disciplinary divisions between “security” and “development” tend to blur. This class uses history to investigate the interplay between the two. We look at important historical cases, including European chartered monopolies in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, wartime blockades in the Napoleonic Wars and World War I, the “imperialism of free trade,” state-backed overseas private investment, war debts and U.S.-sponsored European reconstruction after World War I, German bilateralism during the 1930s, Bretton Woods and the Marshall Plan, Cold War foreign aid rivalry, OPEC’s 1973 oil embargo, the “Washington Consensus” and structural adjustment, economic sanctions, rival multilateral development banks, and the contemporary geoeconomic strategies of especially Russia and China. The course asks why states sometimes pursue overtly political goals through economic means, how and why economic actors are sometimes able to mobilize political means for private interests, and why both states and private actors sometimes find it in their interests to “depoliticize” international economic relations. Readings include classic and contemporary texts written mainly by historians and political scientists. Students write a research paper on a geoeconomic topic of their choosing, historical or contemporary.
